Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: LTREB: Evolutionary Demography - the Contribution of Adaptation and Environment to Population Dynamics, Range Size, and Niche Width
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project continues a 7-year study of environmental and demographic variation across the geographic range of a native California plant in order to understand the ecological and evolutionary limits on an organism's distribution. Prior work showed that environmental variables related to climate, soils, and interactions with insect pollinators and seed-eaters all change across the plant's range. Population growth rates, a measure of population viability, also decline toward the range edge. Over the next five years, research will examine the role that dormant seeds, which remain buried in the soil for 2-5 years, play in allowing populations to weather adverse environments and persist long-term. The project will also determine range-wide differences in the longevity of dormant seeds.

With impending climate change, parts of the current geographic range of many organisms are likely to become unsuitable for continued persistence. Understanding what limits species from colonizing unfavorable environments now can help forecast species responses to deteriorating conditions within their current range. In addition to its scientific impacts, the project will serve an important educational mission by engaging high school students, undergraduate students from research and primarily undergraduate institutions, and graduate students in research. Project leaders will work with high school students from a rural California high school and from a charter school in St Paul Minnesota through in-class activities and field projects.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Our project examined the contribution of numerical population dynamics and adaptation to the causes of geographic range limits in an annual plant, Clarkia xantiana. Understanding the causes of geographic range limits is a fundamental problem in ecology and evolution that remains poorly understood, and is important for predicting species' responses to climate change. Our research involved building a 12-year dataset on plant population demography in 36 populations from across the species' range. We also conducted detailed studies of biotic interactions from the center to margin of the range (plant-herbivore, plant-pollinator, and plant-microbe) and asked how those interactions might influence the location of the range limit. Finally, we conducted a large reciprocal transplant experiment that examined the contribution of local adaptation to population persistence across the range. 

We found evidence that population growth rates decline from range center to margin across all years. That pattern of population growth was weakened by the megadrought in California that coincided with most of the funding period for this award. Thus, our research serendipitously included an unusual climate event that might be pivotal to understanding the long-term population dynamics and adaptation of this species. 

We also documented a strong pattern of declining insect herbivory from range center to margin, indicating that populations at the range edge tend to escape herbivory. Interestingly, our long-term dataset revealed striking link between herbivore pressure and climate variation. Our results show that climate variation drives fluctuations in the abundance of insect herbivores, which spill over into subsequent years and affect plant populations. Therefore, herbivory in any given year is predicted strongest by the climate of previous years. Our models with only a few factors have remarkable explanatory power. 

We also documented a sharp increase in mammalian herbivory at the range margin and beyond the range edge. This fatal herbivory has important consequences for plant population persistence beyond the range edge. In the absence of herbivory, populations may have the potential to persist beyond the range margin. 

We are currently integrating our long-term findings into species distribution models that examine the distribution of suitable habitat across the geographic range (and beyond) and identify key environmental factors that affect population performance distribution.
